We may further simplify the form of our inequality: On account of eq.~(\ref{EFT-validity}) and the fact that the rhs of eq.~(\ref{main-result-full}) is of order $1$, we may take $9 (c_s^{-2} - 1) \ll M^2 / H^2$ and Taylor expand the square root of eq.~(\ref{main-result-full}) to obtain back (\ref{main-result}). As a result, we see that $c_s$ cannot be much smaller than unity. Indeed, from FIG.~\ref{fig:fig_02} we see that the sound speed cannot be smaller than $c_s \simeq 0.4$ when the rhs of the inequality equals to $1$. In the case of supergravities with many chiral fields, the qualitative content of this result will remain valid. In those cases the rhs of~(\ref{main-result-full}) will not change, and we only need to worry about the lhs. There, $c_s$ will have a similar dependence on the masses of the heavy fields to that of eq.~(\ref{cs-Omega}) (see ref.~\cite{Cespedes:2013rda}). Moreover, the form of $\eta_V$ will change due to the new matrix entries, determined by the masses of the additional fields orthogonal to the trajectory. However, it turns out that these contributions do not modify $\eta_V$ importantly if the masses of the extra fields are of the same order than that along the $N^a$ direction.


\section{Conclusions}

In conclusion, our results reveal that single field EFT's realized within $\mathcal N = 1$ supergravities necessarily have a sound speed $c_s$ close to $1$. An immediate consequence of this is that non-Gaussianity in supergravity inflation must be suppressed unless a second degree of freedom participates of the fluctuation's dynamics. The importance of this may be appreciated more clearly by reverting the statement as follows: If observations ever confirm the existence of sizable non-Gaussianity, produced by a single degree of freedom, then supergravity models should be disfavored.
